a good and informative video overall, however, i'd like to touch on 2 subjects, both of which kind of play of of each other.

the first part would be the "lesser of 2 evils" with the car comparison, i get that making a car that is less environmentally damaging still has the footprint of being made by processes and costs that are environmentally damaging. and that it's usage is still more damaging to the environment then not using it at all.
however, reality shows that, for a lot of people, goods and services, motorized transport is a necessary evil. whether it's private or public.
but if those processes and costs are about the same for each of them, wouldn't the cleaner car be the better option at that point regardless?
and wouldn't it be better to focus on the transition point, where newer vehicles being made, even with more polluting means, actually start recuperating their initial offset compared to older/less environmentally friendly cars?
also, for the mining of lithium and other chemicals, yes the process of the initial mining and refining is extremely hazardous and costly, however, once it has been mined and has seen its use in say, electric vehicles, or other electronic devices, the incentive to repurpose/recycle these materials compared to discarding them is high enough to warrant whole new recycling industries to pop up, ones that can recycle a large portion of those materials with a far smaller carbon/environmental footprint compared to mining and refining the raw materials.

at that point we can extrapolate the "lesser of 2 evils" to the conclusion that anything other then walking would be environmentally damaging.
and before someone says "well, you can always take a bike"... even those have a carbon footprint in their construction that is larger then not having one...
so i would personally call it the "lesser of 2 necessary evils" and I will gladly take the lesser of 2 necessary evils.

as for the second point,
you mention the keystone pipeline, which is a very interesting subject in more ways then 1.
considering the fact that the transport of oil will still be a necessity that will happen, (a, necessary evil if you will) and if the pipeline isn't/won't be complete, which by the looks of it wont happen for quite a while longer at this point, what is the environmental impact of transporting the same amount of oil by other means compared to the pipeline? (the, lesser of 2 evils)

and wouldn't the pipeline, despite having a negative environmental impact, be far less polluting than transporting the same amount of oil by trains, boats or trucks?


also, the chance of accidents/spills/disasters, and how to handle/clean these, would be far less likely to occur, and far easier to fix/clean up, using a pipeline compared to other modes of transport.

so, once again, a lesser of 2 necessary evils scenario.

Is the cancellation of the Keystone Pipeline really environmentally friendly?   Are you claiming the pipeline itself is bad for the environment? And would transporting that same oil in hundreds of tanker trucks every day to the refineries or by lots and lots of trains be more environmentally friendly?  Thus,  when you consider these points, the only real argument you can raise about why the pipeline could be harmful to the environment involves the off chance that a leak occurs.  But the pipeline is not deep under water but rather on land and the flow of oil can easily be turned off so that the leak can be plugged.  So the possible harm is minimal.

This was a good video that debunked some pretty pervasive rumors in our society. I would like to correct a bit of (presumably unintentional) electric vehicle misinformation. Even if an electric vehicle is powered by coal, it is still cleaner than a petrol or diesel car. A coal fired plant is close to 50% efficient in converting fossil fuels to energy, whereas gas engines are in the 25-35% range. When combined with all the waste of extraction, refining, and transportation of fuel, even the worst coal plant is better than continuing to burn gas in cars. Add to this that the EV doesn't leave poison in its wake as it drives past schools and homes, and at least with the coal power plant the particulate pollution is centralized away from most people's lungs. Furthermore, given the trend of most power grids to renewable energy, an EV will just get cleaner, whereas a gas car will only get dirtier as it gets old and worn out. And if you're concerned with the extraction of things from the ground to make batteries, I have two points to make there. First, there are batteries in phones and laptops and all kinds of things, and nobody was upset about it until they started showing up in cars. Second, oil is a thing that has to be extracted from the ground, and then it's burned and never used again. An EV battery will last at least 10 years, and after that another 20 or so for balancing the grid (gotta store renewables somewhere) and then the vast majority of the materials that went into the production of the battery will be able to be used again, instead of extracting further things from the ground. Gotta bust the fossil fuel FUD when I see it, especially when I suspect it's unintentional.

I always laugh when it comes to the "but VW etc. used software to get around the tests" - yes, they did and it was wrong, but you know what's wrong too? The way these tests work in the US. In the US the gas mileage of a vehicle is not considered at all when it comes to emissions. All that counts is that the engine in the vehicle can burn whatever fuel the engine uses cleanly below thresholds. So for example: a big SUV getting 5mpg is considered clean because the engine in it can burn 1 gallon of fuel below the legally allowable emissions. Nobody in the US cares that the vehicle burns hundreds of gallons of fuel to go places that another vehicle could do with a fraction of the pollution.  So a BMW 4 series Diesel - which gets up to 47mpg without complicated hybrid technology is illegal in the US - because it burns one gallon of diesel above the allowable emissions. Again, nobody cares that the SUV or Pickup next door uses 15 to 20 gallons to go 100 miles when the BMW uses less than 3 for the same distance. This way of testing was made in favor of the oil industry and is a classic case of greenwashing.

The Seven Sins of Greenwashing:
1. 0:53 Hidden Trade Off: when a company highlights the importance of fixing one environmental issue while potentially hiding a more concerning one (e.g. Nestle).
2. 2:38 No Proof: when organisations make environmental claims that they have no evidence for (e.g. Google Nest).
3. 3:27 Vagueness: related to catchphrases like ‘green’ or ‘eco-friendly’, which are so vague companies use them exploiting loopholes in their definitions, misleading consumers into buying their - not actually so green - products.
4. 5:09 Irrelevance: when an environmental claim is not helpful nor relevant (e.g. CFCs banned in 197 countries across the world because of their environmental impact, yet companies still find the need to emphasise that products are CFC-free in an attempt to appear as if they’re taking responsibility for protecting the environment).
5. 6:03 Lesser of Two Evils: when a slightly less harmful product is created in an environmentally harmful field it’s often touted very loudly (e.g. cars labelled as fuel efficient while still significantly adding to CO2 emissions worldwide. Sometimes reducing or completely minimize our use of services or products is actually the most impactful thing we can do).
6. 6:37 Fibbing: the name means 'outright false claims' by corporations (e.g. In 2015 the (US) Environmental Protection Agency found that vehicle manufacturers like Volkswagen among others used emission cheating software when external testing took place in their facilities).
7. 7:31 Worshipping False Labels: related to hundreds of third-party certifications and claims given to products with no real guarantee the claims are true (e.g. paper towels products with a “fights global warming” certification).

The three R’s (reduce, reuse, recycle) are in that order for a reason.
- First, reduce as much as you can. Reduce is the most important R, it’s the one thing we can do as consumers to make a gigantic difference. Consume less of everything, eat less high-emission foods like animal products, non-local foods and out of season foods, make it a goal to create less trash, choose the option that create less emissions and trash like public transport, dine-in instead of takeout, staycations. Trash is really the #1 way to make an impact so do your best to minimize your garbage.
- Then reuse what you already have. Don’t do things like throw away your plastic tupperware to buy glass tupperware, buy all things second hand whenever possible, choose quality over quantity where applicable
- And when there is absolutely nothing else you can do, recycle.

To make things easier for your future self, try to always, always think about what’ll happen when that item you want to buy is done/broken/used up and implement the three R’s in the correct order;
Reduce - do I really need this, and do I need it right now?
Reuse - can I buy this second hand? Can this item be resold/reused when I’m done with it?
Recycle - is this item recyclable if it breaks or becomes unusable in some other way? If your answer is no or maybe to any of them, buy it second hand or don’t buy it at all. 9/10 times you’ll realize that there is a better option or that you don’t need it.

Plus, you’ll save time and a bunch of money when you go low-waste!
